title: Porifera
description:
A phylum of simple, porous-bodied invertebrates.
Example: Sponges

title: Ostia
description:
Small pores on sponges allowing water intake.
Example: Sycon

title: Osculum
description:
A large opening in sponges for water exit.
Example: Leucosolenia

title: Choanocytes
description:
Cells in sponges that filter food.
Example: Grantia

title: Spongin
description:
A protein forming sponge skeletons.
Example: Bath Sponge

title: Cnidaria
description:
A phylum of aquatic invertebrates with stinging cells.
Example: Jellyfish

title: Nematocyst
description:
A stinging organelle in cnidarians.
Example: Sea Anemone

title: Medusa
description:
A free-swimming, bell-shaped stage in cnidarians.
Example: Aurelia

title: Polyp
description:
A sessile stage in cnidarians.
Example: Hydra

title: Anthozoa
description:
A class of cnidarians including corals.
Example: Coral Reefs

title: Ctenophora
description:
A phylum of marine invertebrates using cilia for movement.
Example: Pleurobrachia

title: Platyhelminthes
description:
A phylum of flatworms, many parasitic.
Example: Tapeworm

title: Turbellaria
description:
A class of free-living flatworms.
Example: Planaria

title: Trematoda
description:
A class of parasitic flatworms.
Example: Liver Fluke

title: Cestoda
description:
A class of parasitic flatworms lacking a digestive system.
Example: Taenia

title: Rotifera
description:
A phylum of microscopic invertebrates.
Example: Bdelloid Rotifers

title: Nematoda
description:
A phylum of roundworms.
Example: Ascaris

title: Annelida
description:
A phylum of segmented worms.
Example: Earthworm

title: Polychaeta
description:
A class of annelids with numerous bristles.
Example: Nereis

title: Oligochaeta
description:
A class of annelids with fewer bristles.
Example: Earthworm

title: Hirudinea
description:
A class of annelids known as leeches.
Example: Medicinal Leech

title: Mollusca
description:
A phylum of soft-bodied invertebrates.
Example: Snail

title: Bivalvia
description:
A class of mollusks with two hinged shells.
Example: Clam

title: Gastropoda
description:
A class of mollusks with a single spiraled shell.
Example: Garden Snail

title: Cephalopoda
description:
A class of mollusks with tentacles.
Example: Octopus

title: Radula
description:
A feeding organ in mollusks.
Example: Snails

title: Arthropoda
description:
A phylum of invertebrates with jointed legs.
Example: Insects

title: Exoskeleton
description:
A hard outer covering in arthropods.
Example: Beetles

title: Chitin
description:
A tough material forming arthropod exoskeletons.
Example: Crustaceans

title: Crustacea
description:
A subphylum including crabs and lobsters.
Example: Shrimp

title: Arachnida
description:
A class of arthropods including spiders.
Example: Tarantula

title: Insecta
description:
A class of arthropods with six legs.
Example: Butterfly

title: Echinodermata
description:
A phylum of marine invertebrates with radial symmetry.
Example: Starfish

title: Water Vascular System
description:
A system in echinoderms for movement.
Example: Sea Urchin

title: Tube Feet
description:
Suction-like appendages in echinoderms.
Example: Starfish

title: Madreporite
description:
A plate in echinoderms regulating water intake.
Example: Sea Star

title: Regeneration
description:
Ability to regrow lost body parts.
Example: Planaria

title: Metamorphosis
description:
A process where invertebrates change form.
Example: Butterfly

title: Molting
description:
Shedding of the exoskeleton.
Example: Crab

title: Torsion
description:
A developmental process in gastropods.
Example: Snail

title: Parthenogenesis
description:
Reproduction without fertilization.
Example: Aphids

title: Bioluminescence
description:
The ability to produce light.
Example: Firefly

title: Sessile
description:
Fixed in one place.
Example: Coral

title: Planktonic
description:
Drifting with ocean currents.
Example: Krill

title: Filter Feeding
description:
Filtering tiny organisms from water.
Example: Clams

title: Hermaphroditism
description:
Having both male and female reproductive organs.
Example: Earthworms

title: Colony Formation
description:
Living in cooperative groups.
Example: Coral Reefs

title: Hydrostatic Skeleton
description:
A fluid-based support system.
Example: Earthworm

title: Spiracle
description:
Respiratory openings in arthropods.
Example: Grasshopper

title: Book Lungs
description:
Respiratory structures in arachnids.
Example: Spiders

title: Compound Eye
description:
A visual organ made of multiple lenses.
Example: Dragonfly

title: Chelicerae
description:
Mouthparts in arachnids.
Example: Scorpions

title: Pedipalps
description:
Sensory appendages in arachnids.
Example: Spiders

title: Mandibles
description:
Jaw-like structures in arthropods.
Example: Ants

title: Trochophore
description:
A larval stage in mollusks and annelids.
Example: Marine Worms

title: Nauplius
description:
A larval stage in crustaceans.
Example: Shrimp

title: Swimmerets
description:
Appendages in crustaceans for swimming.
Example: Lobsters

title: Statocyst
description:
A balance organ in invertebrates.
Example: Jellyfish

title: Book Gills
description:
Respiratory structures in horseshoe crabs.
Example: Limulus

title: Proboscis
description:
A tube-like feeding organ.
Example: Butterfly

title: Eutely
description:
Fixed number of cells in an organism.
Example: Rotifers

title: Cloaca
description:
A common exit for digestive and excretory waste.
Example: Amphibians

title: Setae
description:
Bristle-like structures in annelids.
Example: Earthworms

title: Cuticle
description:
A protective outer layer in some invertebrates.
Example: Roundworms

title: Hydroid
description:
A polyp stage in cnidarians.
Example: Hydra

title: Spicule
description:
Supportive structures in sponges.
Example: Sponges

title: Cnidoblast
description:
A cell that produces cnidarian stinging cells.
Example: Jellyfish

title: Planula
description:
A larval stage in cnidarians.
Example: Corals

title: Gastrovascular Cavity
description:
A central cavity for digestion in cnidarians.
Example: Hydra

title: Statolith
description:
A balance organ in some invertebrates.
Example: Jellyfish

title: Cercaria
description:
A larval stage in trematodes.
Example: Schistosoma

title: Miracidium
description:
A ciliated larval stage in trematodes.
Example: Liver Fluke

title: Scolex
description:
An attachment organ in tapeworms.
Example: Tapeworm

title: Proglottid
description:
A segment in tapeworms.
Example: Taenia

title: Oncosphere
description:
A larval stage in tapeworms.
Example: Tapeworm

title: Mastax
description:
A grinding organ in rotifers.
Example: Rotifers

title: Parapodia
description:
Paired appendages in polychaetes.
Example: Polychaetes

title: Nereis
description:
A marine annelid.
Example: Nereis

title: Clitellum
description:
A glandular structure in annelids.
Example: Earthworm

title: Peristomium
description:
The first body segment in annelids.
Example: Earthworm

title: Typhlosole
description:
A fold increasing digestive surface in annelids.
Example: Earthworm

title: Nephridia
description:
Excretory organs in annelids.
Example: Earthworm

title: Glochidium
description:
A parasitic larval stage in bivalves.
Example: Freshwater Mussels

title: Byssus
description:
Thread-like structures in bivalves for attachment.
Example: Mussels

title: Operculum
description:
A protective lid in mollusks.
Example: Snails

title: Hectocotylus
description:
A specialized arm in cephalopods for reproduction.
Example: Octopus

title: Biramous Appendage
description:
Appendages with two branches.
Example: Crustaceans

title: Uniramous Appendage
description:
Appendages with one branch.
Example: Insects

title: Hemocoel
description:
A primary body cavity in arthropods.
Example: Arthropods

title: Tagmata
description:
Fused body segments in arthropods.
Example: Arthropods

title: Malpighian Tubules
description:
Excretory organs in insects and arachnids.
Example: Insects

title: Green Glands
description:
Excretory glands in crustaceans.
Example: Crustaceans

title: Maxillipeds
description:
Feeding appendages in crustaceans.
Example: Crabs

title: Carapace
description:
A hard shell covering the cephalothorax.
Example: Lobsters

title: Rostrum
description:
An extended front part of the carapace.
Example: Prawns

title: Telson
description:
A tail-like structure in crustaceans.
Example: Crayfish

title: Uropods
description:
Tail-like appendages in crustaceans.
Example: Shrimp

title: Ambulacral Groove
description:
A groove in echinoderms containing tube feet.
Example: Starfish

title: Aristotle’s Lantern
description:
A jaw-like feeding structure in sea urchins.
Example: Sea Urchin

title: Pentaradial Symmetry
description:
Five-part radial symmetry in echinoderms.
Example: Sea Stars

title: Dermal Branchiae
description:
Skin gills for respiration in echinoderms.
Example: Starfish

title: Bipinnaria
description:
A larval stage in sea stars.
Example: Starfish

title: Brachiolaria
description:
A later larval stage in sea stars.
Example: Starfish

title: Evisceration
description:
Expelling internal organs for defense.
Example: Sea Stars

title: Ophiopluteus
description:
A larval stage in brittle stars.
Example: Brittle Stars

title: Crinoidea
description:
A class of feather stars and sea lilies.
Example: Feather Stars

title: Holothuroidea
description:
A class of sea cucumbers.
Example: Sea Cucumbers

title: Ossicles
description:
Calcareous plates in echinoderms.
Example: Sea Stars

title: Papulae
description:
Small respiratory structures in echinoderms.
Example: Sea Stars

title: Lophophore
description:
A ciliated feeding organ in some invertebrates.
Example: Bryozoans

title: Trochophore Larva
description:
A larval stage in annelids and mollusks.
Example: Marine Worms

title: Veliger Larva
description:
A larval stage in gastropods and bivalves.
Example: Snails

title: Gastrulation
description:
A developmental process forming germ layers.
Example: Embryos

title: Spiral Cleavage
description:
A cleavage pattern in protostomes.
Example: Mollusks

title: Radial Cleavage
description:
A cleavage pattern in deuterostomes.
Example: Echinoderms

title: Enterocoely
description:
A coelom formation method in deuterostomes.
Example: Echinoderms

title: Schizocoely
description:
A coelom formation method in protostomes.
Example: Annelids

title: Metamerism
description:
Segmental body organization.
Example: Arthropods

title: Tagmatization
description:
Fusion of segments for specialized function.
Example: Cnidarians
